Hi Colin,

Yes, that sounds like a good approach.  This is probably one of =

those cases where there is no need for nondeterminism.  

ken

--- In neat=
@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <locster01@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken, Faisal,
=
> 
> Following on from your suggestions Ken I was thinking that for
> somet=
hing like moving towards a target it probably makes sense to 
take
> N posi=
tions equidistant from the target and also evenly spaced out
> around the c=
ircumference (spaced every 360/N degrees). In addition 
you
> want to evalu=
ate how the agent responds when oriented differently
> relative to the targ=
et, so for each of the N positions perform
> multiple trials with the agent=
 oriented pointing towards, away 
from,
> at 90 degrees etc.
> 
> However, =
if the agent is egocentric then you don't really need the 
N
> trials space=
d around a circumference - they will all amount to
> evaulating the same sc=
enario. You may however want to perform 
trials
> using  3 or 4 different (=
and adjacent) starting poistions if the 
world
> is a grid system because o=
f the subtle sensory differences caused 
by
> aliasing.
> 
> If you do star=
t out at a fixed distance then you can assign fitness
> based on how close =
the agent gets to the target within a fixed 
amount
> of time - averaged ou=
t for each of the different starting
> orientations. Does this seem reasona=
ble?
> 
> Colin
